stem: The nurse is evaluating a client at 38 weeks gestation. For each assessment finding, select whether it indicates True Labor or False (Braxton-Hicks) Labor.

rows.text: Progressive cervical dilation and effacement documented over 2 hours.
Contractions that decrease in intensity with walking or position changes.
Contractions that start in the back and radiate to the lower abdomen.
Irregular contractions felt primarily in the upper abdomen and groin.

rationale.correct: True labor is defined by cervical change. (r1) Cervical dilation and effacement are the definitive markers of true labor. (r2 & r4) False labor contractions often stop with movement (walking) and are felt primarily in the abdomen. (r3) True labor contractions typically radiate from the back to the front and increase in intensity regardless of position.
rationale.incorrect: The 'strength' of a contraction is subjective; only cervical change is an objective indicator of labor progress.
clinicalPearls: Instruct the client to coming to the hospital once contractions are regular (every 5 mins for 1 hour) or if membranes rupture.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that while SROM (rupture of membranes) is an emergency/hospital trigger, it is NOT the definition of labor. Labor = Contractions + Cervical Change.

mnemonic.title: T-R-U-E
mnemonic.expansion: Timed (Regular), Radiating (Back to front), Unchanged by activity, Effacement/Dilation.

reviewUnits.heading: Process of Labor
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must differentiate findings to avoid unnecessary admissions for false labor. Education focuses on when to call the provider (Regular contractions, decreased fetal movement, or fluid leakage).
